title-group.article-title: An investigation into the structures of linear quadratic controllers for vehicle rollover prevention

abstract.p: This paper presents a comparison between structures of linear quadratic controllers for vehicle rollover prevention. Three types of linear quadratic controller, namely a linear quadratic regulator, a structured controller and a separated controller, are compared. These controllers can control yaw and roll motions. The point is whether the yaw motion and the roll motion can be controlled separately for effective rollover prevention. The separation between a yaw motion controller and a roll motion controller is captured by using structured and separated controllers. Simulations on the vehicle simulation software CarSim® are performed to show that a structured controller and a separated controller are equivalent to a linear quadratic regulator for vehicle rollover prevention.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: For the last decade, transportation communities have studied vehicle rollover as it is a disproportionately large contributor of fatal injuries. For example, in 2002, more than 33% of US passenger vehicle occupant fatalities were cause by vehicle rollover, even though it accounts for only 3% of crashes.1 However, in spite of efforts by transportation communities to reduce vehicle rollover, the sport utility vehicle rollover rate in fatal crashes has only slightly decreased over the last decade.2

To date, the most effective commercial device for rollover prevention is electronic stability control (ESC). Generally, rollover involves a vehicle that goes out of control and starts to yaw. ESC with differential braking prevents rollover by controlling the yaw motion.3 A detailed literature review on the effect of ESC on rollover prevention has been given by Ferguson.4 However, even though the yaw motion is stabilized by ESC, rollover occurs if a constant large lateral acceleration is applied. A typical example of this is the fishhook manoeuvre. Under this condition, ESC cannot prevent rollover because ESC is not capable of controlling lateral acceleration. For rollover prevention with ESC, longitudinal speed control with active braking is needed.5 For this reason, a different device is needed to attenuate the effect of the lateral acceleration on the roll motion.

An active roll control system (ARCS) with an active suspension or active anti-roll bar is the most effective way for rollover prevention because it directly controls the roll motion of a vehicle. However, a vehicle with an ARCS has the tendency to lose manoeuvrability under a high lateral acceleration owing to the rear-sway phenomenon.6 For this reason, ESC is essential to maintain manoeuvrability or yaw stability when preventing rollover with an ARCS.

The combination of ESC and an ARCS has a synergetic effect on rollover prevention. Several research studes have adopted both ESC and an ARCS for rollover prevention. There are two ways to design a controller for ESC and an ARCS: a unified approach and a separated approach. A unified approach is to design a controller in a single framework. A representative example of a unified approach is the linear quadratic (LQ) controller, which includes a linear quadratic regulator (LQR) or LQ static output feedback.6,7 A controller for rollover prevention should be able to handle a multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) system because it has two control inputs (one for ESC and the other for the ARCS), and a LQ controller is suitable especially for an MIMO system. A separated approach is to design independent controllers for ESC and the ARCS.6 This approach is based on the premise that the yaw motion and the roll motion are not closely related. As the controllers are designed separately, several types of controller design method such as LQR, sliding-mode control and time-delay control can be applied to design the independent controllers. In this paper, a unified approach and a separated approach are presented in the single framework of LQ control to show that these approaches are equivalent for rollover prevention.

This paper presents a comparison between the unified approach and the separated approach in the single framework of LQ control for designing a rollover prevention controller. Through simulation, it is validated that the coupling effect between the yaw dynamics and the roll dynamics can be ignored by the ARCS. By virtue of this effect, several approaches can be applied to design a yaw motion controller. Moreover, the ARCS can also be designed by several approaches. The previously proposed combination of an ARCS with ESC is adopted, as employed by Yim et al.6 Simulations on the vehicle simulation software CarSim® are performed to demonstrate the effect of the controller structure on vehicle rollover prevention. From simulation results, it is shown that a unified approach and a separated approach are equivalent for rollover prevention.

This paper is organized as follows. A state-space equation from a vehicle model is derived, and a unified controller and separated controllers are designed with the vehicle model in the second section. In the third section, simulations are conducted via Carsim. The fourth section concludes this paper.

sec.title: Design of the LQR
sec.p: The LQ cost function for rollover prevention is defined as
In equation (15), the weights ρi are set by the relation ρi=1/ηi2 from Bryson’s rule, where ηi represents the maximum allowable value of each term.11

To avoid rollover in cornering situations, the roll angle and the roll rate should be reduced under the assumption that the lateral acceleration is uncontrollable. If the weights on the roll angle and the roll rate are set to higher values for rollover prevention, the yaw rate error increases owing to the lateral load transfer caused by the ARCS, and this can make a vehicle lose manoeuvrability or lateral stability because of the rear-sway phenomenon.6 On the other hand, if the weight on the yaw rate error is set to a higher value for manoeuvrability or lateral stability, the roll angle and the roll rate cannot be decreased. These effects are complementary to each other. In other words, the ARCS can reduce the roll angle and roll rate which ESC cannot do, and ESC can reduce the yaw rate error which the ARCS cannot do. For this reason, the weights on the roll angle, the roll rate and the yaw rate error, i.e. ρ1, ρ3 and ρ4 in equation (15), should be set to higher values in the LQ objective function. sec.title: Design of the structured controller and the separated controllers
sec.p: As mentioned in the section on the vehicle model, the controllers for the yaw motion and the roll motion can be designed separately if the ARCS can reduce the roll motion. To confirm this fact, a structured controller and a separated controller are designed.

In a structured controller, the control yaw moment is calculated only from the yaw rate error, and the control roll moment is calculated only from the roll angle and the roll rate. The controller structure is given by

In a structured LQ controller, it is necessary to find Ks which minimizes the LQ cost function J. With the notation in equation (16), the problem of finding Ks is formulated as the optimization problem

For an arbitrary Ks, the LQ cost function J can be easily computed by solving the Lyapunov equation (18). The evolutionary strategy with covariance matrix adaptation (CMA-ES)12 is used to find the optimal Ks.

The structured controller given by equation (17) is designed for the single objective function (15). In this situation, the controller gains for the yaw moment and the roll moment have an effect on each other. This means that the structured controller does not strictly separate the yaw motion and the roll motion. Hence, it is necessary to design separately a controller for yaw motion and a controller for roll motion with different objective functions. Therefore two LQ controllers are designed separately for yaw motion control and roll motion control. To find Ks1 and Ks2, the CMA-ES is also used.

sec.title: Design of the controllers for an ARCS with ESC
sec.p: For comparison, an ARCS with ESC is designed as in the work by Yim et al.6 In this approach, the ARCS and ESC are separately designed. The ARCS is designed with the LQ static output feedback control method based on a linear four-degree-of-freedom roll plane model.6 In the LQ objective function given by Yim et al.,6 the weights that strongly emphasize the roll angle and the roll rate show quite a good performance in preventing rollover. However, the vehicle with the ARCS lost its manoeuvrability owing to the rear-sway phenomenon. To cope with this problem, ESC was designed with sliding-mode control.6

sec.title: Simulation of an uncontrolled vehicle
sec.p: To show the characteristics of the vehicle roll motion, simulations were performed on the non-linear multi-body dynamic simulation software CarSim. In the simulation, the steering input is a fixed fishhook manoeuvre14 with a maximum angle of 221°. The initial speeds of the vehicle are set to 50 km/h, 60 km/h, 70 km/h and 80 km/h, and the tyre–road friction coefficient is set to 1.0. There are no speed controls to maintain a constant speed.

Figures 2 and 3 show the simulation results for an uncontrolled vehicle at each initial speed. As shown in Figure 2(a), the lateral accelerations were nearly the same, irrespective of the initial speed. As a result, the roll angles were nearly the same. This fact indicates that the lateral acceleration is hard to control. For this reason, previous studies have concentrated on controlling the roll motion under the assumption that the lateral acceleration is an uncontrollable disturbance.6 An uncontrolled vehicle with an initial speed of 80 km/h drifted, as shown in Figures 2(c) and 3. This is the rear-sway phenomenon, which is caused by the fact that the vehicle turns around the front outer wheel when the inner wheels are lifted in cornering and, consequently, the lateral tyre force of the rear outer wheel becomes small compared with that of the front outer wheel. With yaw motion control or ESC, it is possible to prevent the rear-sway phenomenon.

sec.p: As shown in Figure 2(d), the roll acceleration is sufficiently large to have an effect on the yaw motion. As mentioned in the section on the vehicle model, the effect of roll on the yaw motion can be ignored if the ARCS can reduce the roll acceleration. Hence, the yaw motion controller and the roll motion controller can be designed separately by virtue of the ARCS.

sec.title: Linear system analysis for the designed controllers
sec.p: Figure 4 shows the Bode plots drawn on the basis of the designed LQ controllers. In these plots, the input is the steering angle, and the outputs are the roll angle, the roll rate, the lateral acceleration and the yaw rate error. Since the frequency of the fishhook manoeuvre with a maximum steering angle of 221° is near 0.5 Hz, the frequency responses near 0.5 Hz should be focused on.6

sec.p: As shown in Figure 4, the structured LQ controller and the separated LQ controllers show almost the same performance. This is caused by the fact that the yaw motion and the roll motion of a the controlled vehicle were not related to each other. This result means that the controllers for the yaw motion and the roll motion can be separately designed according to their own objectives and that several approaches can be applied to design the controllers for the yaw motion and the roll motion.

sec.title: Rollover prevention control for the CarSim vehicle model
sec.p: To check the performance of the designed LQ controllers for rollover prevention, simulations were performed. The simulation conditions are identical with those in the section on simulation of an uncontrolled vehicle. The actuators of the brake and the active anti-roll bar are modelled as a first-order system with time constants of 0.12 and 0.08 respectively. To prevent locking of the brake, the anti-lock braking system (ABS) provided in CarSim is used. The operating range of the slip ratio in the ABS is between 0.05 and 0.15. For roll motion control, it is necessary to measure or estimate the roll angle and the roll rate. In a real situation, it is hard to measure those states. Therefore, an open-loop observer was adopted to estimate those states in the simulation.17,18

To generate the control yaw moment MB and the control roll moment Mφ in a real vehicle, it is necessary to distribute them into the braking pressures at the four wheels and at the active anti-roll bars at the front axle and the rear axle respectively. For the roll moment distribution, half of Mφ is applied to each active anti-roll bar at the front axle and the rear axle. For the yaw moment distribution, weighted pseudo-inverse-based control allocation was adopted.7

Figures 5, 6 and 7 show the responses of the SmallSUV model and control inputs under the fixed fishhook manoeuvre at 221° and 80 km/h. As shown in Figure 5(a), the lateral accelerations are nearly identical for each controller although the lateral acceleration slightly decreases on braking by ESC compared with the uncontrolled vehicle. This indicates that the lateral acceleration is rarely affected by ESC. There are differences in the yaw rate error and the roll angle, as shown in Figure 5(c) and (d). The LQR is the best in controlling the roll angle, and active roll control (ARC)+ ESC is the best in controlling the yaw rate error. Generally, the more the roll angle is reduced, the more the yaw rate error increases, because there is slight effect of the roll motion on the yaw motion, as shown in Figure 5(b). If the weights on the roll angle and the roll rate in Table 1 were set to lower values, then the LQR and ARC+ESC would show identical roll and yaw responses.

sec.p: As shown in Figure 5(b), the roll acceleration is reduced by the LQ controllers or the ARCS. This means that the effect of roll on the yaw motion is reduced. Hence, the yaw motion and the roll motion can be controlled separately by virtue of the ARCS. As a result, the structured controller and the separated controllers give nearly identical results, as shown in Figure 5. Although these controllers are designed using the CMA-ES, the separated controllers are preferred because this approach is simpler than the structured approach and because the LQR and several approaches can be applied to control the yaw motion and the roll motion.

The structured controller and the separated controllers show slightly poor responses for the roll angle and the yaw rate error, compared with the LQR and ARC +ESC. However, this can be ignored in view of rollover prevention. As shown in Figure 7(a), the structured LQ controller and the separated LQ controllers show slightly more understeer–oversteer characteristics, compared with the LQR and ARC+ESC. As shown in Figure 7(b), all the LQ controllers have nearly equivalent yaw-rate-tracking performances. From these results, it can be concluded that the yaw motion controller and the roll motion controller can be designed separately to prevent rollover and that the separated controllers are preferable to the structured controller and the LQR.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, three types of LQ controller, namely an LQR, a structured contoller and a separated controller, are compared in terms of rollover prevention. According to the yaw and roll motion controls, the LQ controller can be structured or separated. This is accomplished by the fact that the effect of roll on the yaw motion can be reduced by the ARCS. From a Bode plot analysis and simulations on CarSim, it is shown that the LQR, the structured contoller and the separated controllers are equivalent to one another for rollover prevention. From this fact, it can be concluded that a rollover prevention controller can be designed separately according to the control objective, i.e. yaw motion control and roll motion control, and that several approaches for the yaw motion and the roll motion can be applied separately to design the separated controllers.
